sense.name: deliver a quick blow or poke; hit the surface of but not penetrate.
sense.examples: An irate parent punched the coach in the face at the last game. She rapidly punched the keys of her cell phone. If the store clerk had punched the card number in manually, there would have been no problem.

sense.name: move or drive forcefully as if by a punch.
sense.commentary: Syntax is: NP1 PUNCH PP Note: involves penetration of an object at a single point (may be concrete or abstract, as in a space). INCLUDES: PUNCH THROUGH, PUNCH INTO, PUNCH IN, PUNCH OUT
sense.examples: Israeli troops punched into south Lebanon on Wednesday. The nail punched through the wall. He punched in a three-pointer from the corner for the win. Voters cannot see that the punch has punched out the appropriate chad. As each column is punched, the card advances automatically to the next punching position.

sense.name: weaken by revealing internal inconsistencies or inadequacies.
sense.commentary: Syntax is: NP1[agent] PUNCH (NP2[product]) PP{in NP[patient[abstract]]}
sense.examples: Today, in their final effort to punch holes in the Government's case, defense lawyers used four wiretapped conversations.

sense.name: Register one's arrival at work
sense.examples: What time do you usually punch in?

sense.name: Register one's departure from work
sense.examples: After I punched out, I went straight to the parking lot and drove home.

sense.name: Improve or intensify
sense.examples: Innovative ideas lead to punched-up profits. They punched up the arrangement of the song. Here I decided that the image was a little flat and so I punched up the contrast.

sense.name: Invoke on a computer.
sense.examples: Let me punch up that website for you.

sense.name: Produce, as on a typing instrument.
sense.examples: His typewriter's last hurrah was helping him punch out his doctoral dissertation at Harvard.

sense.name: Defeat an opponent.
sense.examples: As an SLNN writer, I was punched out for stories time and time again until I finally got one. Ali finally punched out the other boxer.

sense.name: Offer a rebuttal, as in an argument.
sense.examples: She punched back by citing an argument from Kant. He punched back, invoking a string of facts from high school physics.
